"Our goal with this review is to identify sensible and concrete recommendations‚Äî¬≠legislative or otherwise‚Äîthat recognize the benefits of this technology, but protect against its abuse. -Chairman @RepCummings

‚ÄúYou could be pressing for the repeal of the ACA or the expansion of healthcare. In all of those cases, the government could monitor you without your knowledge and enter your face into a database that could be used in virtually unrestricted ways.‚Äù

‚ÄúThink about that-whatever walk of  life you come from. You could be at a rally supporting gun rights or protesting gun violence. You could be marching for the right to life or a woman's right to choose.‚Äù
‚Äú#Facialrecognition is a fascinating technology with huge potential to affect a number of different applications. But right now, it is virtually unregulated.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want to make clear at the outset that this is a bipartisan issue. Both conservatives and liberals alike have real questions about when they are being monitored, why they are being monitored, who is monitoring them, and what happens to this information after it is collected.‚Äù

‚ÄúToday, we are having our first hearing of this Congress on the use of #facialrecognition technology. ‚ÄúTruvada for #PReP is only getting to 10% of the people that need it. What about the other 90%? What about their families?‚Äù‚ÄìChairman @RepCummings 
Skyrocketing drug costs are hurting everyday Americans. @HouseDemocrats are committed to holding companies accountable #ForThePeople pic.twitter.com/aCmfDBCTXC

"#Gilead recently agreed to donate millions of bottles of this drug, but far short of what we need.  Without addressing the fundamental problem of pricing, I am afraid that we simply may not get there." -@RepCummings

"This life-saving treatment would not exist but for the research funded by the CDC and NIH.  So how can our system let a company charge prices that are so outrageous‚Äîmaking $36 billion‚Äîwhile there are literally hundreds of thousands of people who need this drug?"
"In that same time period, #Gilead has made massive windfalls on this treatment‚Äîmore than $36 billion in revenues.  Let me say that again‚Äî$36 billion on this drug alone."
"Since then, #Gilead has raised the price of this drug over, and over, and over again.  It now charges about $2,000 for just one month, or about $70 per pill."
"The problem is that #Gilead, the company that now sells this drug, charges astronomical prices.  When Truvada was first approved in 2004, Gilead charged about $800 per month."
"This treatment was developed as a result of investments made by the American taxpayers through the #NIH and the #CDC."
"Think about this‚Äîwe now have a drug that has the potential to end the #HIVepidemic.  This would have been unfathomable at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis."

"Today is our Committee‚Äôs second hearing on the skyrocketing prices of prescription drugs. We are examining the price of a drug called Truvada. it is a phenomenal drug that prevents the transmission of HIV through a treatment called pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)"- @RepCummings pic.twitter.com/fpYma1V2eU

"Yet, when it comes to white supremacist terror‚Äîthe single greatest domestic terrorist threat to the American people‚Äîwe are clearly falling down on the  job." - @RepRaskin

BREAKING: Chairman @RepCummings Releases New Information on Defense Contractor‚Äôs Extreme Profit Margins! 
Full Memo: https://oversight.house.gov/news/press-releases/committee-releases-new-information-on-defense-contractor-s-extreme-profit¬†‚Ä¶
"The Pentagon asked TransDigm to pay that money back, but the company refused. We will not leave here today without a commitment from TransDigm that it will repay its excess profits." - @RepRoKhanna
"Overall, the Inspector General found that TransDigm made more than $16 million in excess profits just from the contracts reviewed in their small sample. "

"The Committee also obtained documents showing TransDigm employees and Pentagon officials communicating about breaking contracts into multiple smaller contracts to avoid certain reporting requirements. If that is true, it would violate federal contracting rules."
"Today, we will hear directly from the Inspector General about TransDigm's actions, and they are reprehensible."

"Two years ago, I asked the Inspector General of the Department of Defense to investigate a defense contractor named TransDigm.  TransDigm supplies spare parts for a number of military aircraft that we use in Afghanistan, Iraq, and around the world. "

"What we will not tolerate are war profiteers‚Äîthose who use the fact that we are at war to hold us hostage and hike their prices on mission-critical defense articles to astronomical levels¬∑ because they know we have nowhere else to go."
"Our nation has been at war for almost two decades. We owe it to our service members to give them everything they need to fulfill their missions in the battlefield.' - @RepRoKhanna

WATCH: Trump Admin ONDCP Director commends ‚Äúheart and spirit‚Äù of Chairman @RepCummings' bill to finally start treating the #opioidcrisis like the emergency it is. #TheCAREAct provides sustained funding for treatment in red, blue & purple states. pic.twitter.com/IhCnES8vgx

"#TheCAREAct will finally start treating the #opioidepidemic like the public health emergency it is. And it will help people in red states, blue states, and purple states who are suffering without adequate access to treatment." - Rep. @GerryConnolly
"This landmark legislation would finally provide stable and sustained resources to expand treatment to those who so desperately need it."
That is why every Democratic Member of this Committee joined together yesterday to introduce #TheCAREAct, which stands for the Comprehensive Addiction Resources Emergency Act.

"This is a frightening projection. We have to do better. We have to fight harder. The #opioidcrisis is the most devastating health emergency our nation has faced in a generation. And we need a bold strategy to meet this challenge head on."

"For example, there were approximately 70,000 overdoses deaths in 2017. But the Administration's plan seeks to reduce overdose deaths by only 15% over five years. At that pace, more than 200,000 Americans will die between 2019 and 2022 even if ONDCP meets all of their goals."

"Today, we are holding our 2nd hearing on the #TrumpAdmin's response to the #opioidcrisis. At our 1st hearing, we heard testimony about the #TrumpAdmin's failure to issue a National Drug Control Strategy for 2 years while tens of thousands of people died."- Rep.@GerryConnolly

ICYMI: Watch Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Subcommittee Chairman @RepRaskin opening from today‚Äôs hearing examining  election practices. 

"We can do so much better as a society by enlarging the opportunities for voting!" pic.twitter.com/wRaTqkds2Q

‚ÄúSo today we are going to showcase both three of the best practices today in protecting the vote a long with the three worst practices cancelling out voter rights and opportunities.‚Äù‚Äì Chairman @RepRaskin

‚ÄúVoting in American life has an ideal history and a real history. There is no more celebrated ideal than that of voting rights for all, but in reality there have been constant efforts to lock people out of the franchise and to keep them from participating as equal citizens.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt has only been through waves of profound social and political struggle and constitutional and statutory changes that we have opened America up to change and inclusion.‚Äù

‚ÄúA great Republican President once spoke of government "of the people, by the  people, for the people," and this has been the tantalizing ideal of America. But it has not always been  like that in our  country‚Äù ‚Äì Chairman @RepRaskin pic.twitter.com/jPwSAnDcRm
